results.title: Almost everything you ever wanted to know about motivating people or Maslow's hierarchy of needs
results.brief_description: Instructional film which uses psychologist Abraham Maslow’s “Hierarchy of needs” model to explore how to increase worker productivity. The model posits five levels of need - physiological, security, social, esteem and finally, and most importantly, self-actualisation. Film uses short, fictional, badly acted scenarios to illustrate how each need can be satisfied in the workplace, and how damaging it is if each need is not satisfied. The point is made explicit that we don’t satisfy worker needs for their benefit, because it is humane and civilised, but because a happy worker will be more efficient and productive, thus more profitable.

results.title: Almost everyone does
results.creator_credit: Wombat Productions, Inc. and Gene Feldman
results.brief_description: Scenes from an average middle-class family illustrate what they do to unwind- martinis, smoking, chatting, pills. The film asks, “When does a drug that changes the way a person feels become harmful or dangerous?”. Emphasises that all people have good and bad feelings, and suggests how people learn to cope with them. Explores alternatives to coping with bad feelings without recourse to drugs.

results.title: Almos' a man
results.creator_credit: Dan McCann, Stan Lathan and Perspective Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The American Short Story”.
Dave - a black, teenage worker - buys a used hand gun and accidentally kills a mule. Consequently, his father demeans him in front of the landowner, who demands that he work 25 months to pay for the animal. At nightfall, aimed with vague notions of manhood and independence, Dave retrieves his gun and hops aboard a passing train.

results.title: Alma de Groen
results.creator_credit: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Alma De Groen is one of Australia’s most innovative and challenging playwrights. This interview offers an enlightening introduction to her work. She speaks about her early plays and the emergence of her interest in the outsider figure, feminism, and developments in her latest work. She also discusses the inspiration she seeks from the work of visual artists for the form and style of her plays. Interviewed by Elizabeth Perkins.

results.title: Allures
results.brief_description: Abstract animation by Jordon Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. It consists of sequences featuring interplay of dots, lines, planes, intricate kaleidoscopic designs, circles, grids, rhythms, textures, intensities and variations of focus. The images themselves often suggest the infinity of outer space or of subatomic particles, the snappy impersonality of computers or the undulation of romantic coloured clouds, provide filmed contrasts and tensions complemented by a musical soundtrack which itself acts as a counterpoint.

results.title: Allies
results.creator_credit: Sylvie Le Clezio, Cinema Enterprises and Marian Wilkinson
results.brief_description: A frank look at the relations between Australia and the United States since 1945 and the cost of that friendship. It is the story, told by men with first-hand involvement, of the cold war in Australia and the setting up of ASIO; it is the story of Sir Robert Menzies’ ambitions to follow the U.S. into Vietnam in order to demonstrate loyalty to the alliance.

results.title: Allegro non troppo
results.brief_description: A parody of the Disney film “Fantasia”, “Allegro non troppo” features the highly creative work of talented Italian animator Bruno Bozzetto. It transcends the genre of parody to become a beautiful film in its own right. There are six animated sequences set to classical music, linked together by live-action scenes subtitled in English. The all-female orchestra is composed of old women and directed by a mad conductor (Maurizio Nichetti). This version features ten minutes of previously unreleased music and includes the music of Debussy, Dvorak, Ravel, Sibelius, Vivaldi and Stravinsky.
